content.raw:
I merged default into this branch and changed `config.yaml` so all target locations are in open areas, and also copied the resulting initial pose to `amcl_diff.launch` (branch `wjwwood_nav_tuning_louise`).

Even though it started with a map perfectly matching the sensor readings, the robot wasn't able to trace a path from the private cafe (the open one) to the front entrance. Then I started giving it intermediate goals and it progressed with a lot of difficulty, often bumping into walls.

What would be the one thing to focus on to improve this? Is it mainly an odometry problem because the wheel is slipping?
content.html:
I merged default into this branch and changed config.yaml so all target locations are in open areas, and also copied the resulting initial pose to amcl_diff.launch (branch wjwwood_nav_tuning_louise).

Even though it started with a map perfectly matching the sensor readings, the robot wasn't able to trace a path from the private cafe (the open one) to the front entrance. Then I started giving it intermediate goals and it progressed with a lot of difficulty, often bumping into walls.

What would be the one thing to focus on to improve this? Is it mainly an odometry problem because the wheel is slipping?

content.raw:
I was able to navigate in and out of the kitchen/cafe, whatever it's called, I'll spend a bit more time on going in and out of doors.

Do we really need to do that? Could we demonstrate the API's and theory of the competition without solving one of the arguably harder tasks (navigating through doors)? Not trying to duck out of work, but I'm just making sure we don't spend a lot of time on something we don't have to necessarily do.

content.raw:
Nice! Do you have an example of trajectory that you know works (like a set of goals / rooms the robot successfully navigate to)?
I tried a few times and can navigate well in open space but couldnt get the robot to enter any room so far. It just keeps rotating in front of the door and with the AMCL drift the costmap end up totally cluttered

pull_request.title: added base_footprint, tighter amcl config, and better rviz config

pullrequest.title: added base_footprint, tighter amcl config, and better rviz config

content.raw:
I updated this branch again. I ended up not using a separate map for amcl and the static map of the costmap, because it didn't end up making much a difference once you consider the shadow the rolling chairs and the computers on the desks, which the robot can see.

If I had more time I'd try hector_mapping or amcl + scan matching for odom-less localization, and also try out TEB local planner, but it's working pretty well atm. It can navigate across the building most times and make it through doors as well, though I think in the cafe there is something strange with the traction of the robot, it seems to be commanding it to turn a lot but the robot sort of strafes forward and sideways instead.

It can still get lost if AMCL looses track of where it is when bumping into something and it can still get stuck when a goal is "inside an obstacle" due to drifting localization.
content.html:
I updated this branch again. I ended up not using a separate map for amcl and the static map of the costmap, because it didn't end up making much a difference once you consider the shadow the rolling chairs and the computers on the desks, which the robot can see.

If I had more time I'd try hector_mapping or amcl + scan matching for odom-less localization, and also try out TEB local planner, but it's working pretty well atm. It can navigate across the building most times and make it through doors as well, though I think in the cafe there is something strange with the traction of the robot, it seems to be commanding it to turn a lot but the robot sort of strafes forward and sideways instead.

It can still get lost if AMCL looses track of where it is when bumping into something and it can still get stuck when a goal is "inside an obstacle" due to drifting localization.

content.raw: Thanks for the pointer. My surprise is that the guest didn't behave as before with the default 1.2m distance. My guess is that is shows up in this PR because the root link of the robot is changed (from `base_link` in the torso to `base_footprint` on the floor). A better way to solve this would be to not take into account the z component when comparing the distance between the robot and the actor. See #!/osrf/servicesim/pull-requests/70 for a potential fix
content.html: Thanks for the pointer. My surprise is that the guest didn't behave as before with the default 1.2m distance. My guess is that is shows up in this PR because the root link of the robot is changed (from base_link in the torso to base_footprint on the floor). A better way to solve this would be to not take into account the z component when comparing the distance between the robot and the actor. See #!/osrf/servicesim/pull-requests/70 for a potential fix

pull_request.title: added base_footprint, tighter amcl config, and better rviz config

pullrequest.title: added base_footprint, tighter amcl config, and better rviz config

content.raw:
You can adjust the distances on the world file like this:

~~~
diff -r bdffdbd4514b servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world
--- a/servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world	Fri Feb 23 19:03:46 2018 -0800
+++ b/servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world	Sat Feb 24 11:43:38 2018 -0800
@@ -47888,6 +47888,12 @@
 
         <namespace>servicesim</namespace>
 
+        <!-- Distance to keep from target, defaults to 1.2 -->
+        <min_distance>2.0</min_distance>
+
+        <!-- Distance beyond which the actor stops following, defaults to 4.0 -->
+        <max_distance>3.0</max_distance>
+
         <!-- FIXME: currently not avoiding obstacles -->
         <ignore_obstacle>walls</ignore_obstacle>
         <ignore_obstacle>floor</ignore_obstacle>
diff -r bdffdbd4514b servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world.erb
--- a/servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world.erb	Fri Feb 23 19:03:46 2018 -0800
+++ b/servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world.erb	Sat Feb 24 11:43:38 2018 -0800
@@ -979,6 +979,12 @@
 
         <namespace>servicesim</namespace>
 
+        <!-- Distance to keep from target, defaults to 1.2 -->
+        <min_distance>2.0</min_distance>
+
+        <!-- Distance beyond which the actor stops following, defaults to 4.0 -->
+        <max_distance>3.0</max_distance>
+
         <!-- FIXME: currently not avoiding obstacles -->
         <ignore_obstacle>walls</ignore_obstacle>
         <ignore_obstacle>floor</ignore_obstacle>
~~~

The command I ran to generate the world file from the erb was (note the seed = 100):

`erb s=100 worlds/service.world.erb > worlds/service.world`
content.html:
You can adjust the distances on the world file like this:

diff -r bdffdbd4514b servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world
--- a/servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world   Fri Feb 23 19:03:46 2018 -0800
+++ b/servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world   Sat Feb 24 11:43:38 2018 -0800
@@ -47888,6 +47888,12 @@

         <namespace>servicesim</namespace>

+        <!-- Distance to keep from target, defaults to 1.2 -->
+        <min_distance>2.0</min_distance>
+
+        <!-- Distance beyond which the actor stops following, defaults to 4.0 -->
+        <max_distance>3.0</max_distance>
+
         <!-- FIXME: currently not avoiding obstacles -->
         <ignore_obstacle>walls</ignore_obstacle>
         <ignore_obstacle>floor</ignore_obstacle>
diff -r bdffdbd4514b servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world.erb
--- a/servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world.erb   Fri Feb 23 19:03:46 2018 -0800
+++ b/servicesim_competition/worlds/service.world.erb   Sat Feb 24 11:43:38 2018 -0800
@@ -979,6 +979,12 @@

         <namespace>servicesim</namespace>

+        <!-- Distance to keep from target, defaults to 1.2 -->
+        <min_distance>2.0</min_distance>
+
+        <!-- Distance beyond which the actor stops following, defaults to 4.0 -->
+        <max_distance>3.0</max_distance>
+
         <!-- FIXME: currently not avoiding obstacles -->
         <ignore_obstacle>walls</ignore_obstacle>
         <ignore_obstacle>floor</ignore_obstacle>

The command I ran to generate the world file from the erb was (note the seed = 100):

erb s=100 worlds/service.world.erb > worlds/service.world

content.raw:
Thanks ! much better rotation on the spot! I faced the issue of the robot getting stuck for no reasons a few times, something to investigate later on.

I didn't succeed to solve the task as the actors are now following me VERY closely but it shouldn't be related to these changes ![Screenshot from 2018-02-23 19-32-52.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/gkR8znK/images/785930060-Screenshot_from_2018-02-23_19-32-52.png)
